body:
In my opinion it is the output of `1D` which is wrong here.
It should be `(B, 1, P, T/2**J)`.
So that then we can work on stereo signals or multichannel signals by replacing the `1` with a `C`, like in `2D`.
@louity what do you think of the 3d current input-output layout? I'm asking you because you documented some of it

> In my opinion it is the output of `1D` which is wrong here.
> It should be `(B, 1, P, T/2**J)`.
> So that then we can work on stereo signals or multichannel signals by replacing the `1` with a `C`, like in `2D`.

Agreed. The only thing that gives me pause here is that the first two dimensions behave the same (that is, they are both "batch" dimensions). It feels redundant. Why should the scattering transform care about what dimension is "batch" and what is "channel"?

A solution to this would be to make it independent of number of dimensions. In other words, `Scattering1D` would always act on the last dimension (convert it to two dimensions), `Scattering2D` on the last two (convert to three), and `Scattering3D` on the last three (convert to four). All preceding dimensions would be "batch" dimensions.

> Agreed. The only thing that gives me pause here is that the first two dimensions behave the same (that is, they are both "batch" dimensions). It feels redundant. Why should the scattering transform care about what dimension is "batch" and what is "channel"?

The batch size remains the same at every layer of a deep learning architecture, whereas the number of channels may change (if you're learning "upmixing" for instance, i.e. mono-to-stereo conversion)

> A solution to this would be to make it independent of number of dimensions. In other words, Scattering1D would always act on the last dimension (convert it to two dimensions), Scattering2D on the last two (convert to three), and Scattering3D on the last three (convert to four). All preceding dimensions would be "batch" dimensions.

I like this. But it requires a considerable effort in raising abstraction in what consitute spatial variables vs scattering path variables. This is exactly the sort of abstraction that I developed in my dissertation (context-sensitive grammar in which scattering paths are lists of lists) and implemented in scattering.m but it seems like Kymatio has taken the direction of hard-coding a lot of assumptions as to which variables should map to which subscript

I should add that whatever decision we take should be informed by future plans of implementing routines for multivariables scattering transforms, including:
* roto-translation
* time-frequency
* 1-D x 1-D  (images in which the horizontal and vertical dimensions are not physically homogeneous)
* 1-D x 2-D (videos)

> The batch size remains the same at every layer of a deep learning architecture, whereas the number of channels may change (if you're learning "upmixing" for instance, i.e. mono-to-stereo conversion)

Sure, but why should this make the scattering transform give "channels" special treatment? At the end of the day, it's just an indexing dimension that is not operated on.
> 
> > A solution to this would be to make it independent of number of dimensions. In other words, Scattering1D would always act on the last dimension (convert it to two dimensions), Scattering2D on the last two (convert to three), and Scattering3D on the last three (convert to four). All preceding dimensions would be "batch" dimensions.
> 
> I like this. But it requires a considerable effort in raising abstraction in what consitute spatial variables vs scattering path variables. This is exactly the sort of abstraction that I developed in my dissertation (context-sensitive grammar in which scattering paths are lists of lists) and implemented in scattering.m but it seems like Kymatio has taken the direction of hard-coding a lot of assumptions as to which variables should map to which subscript

Does it? The way I understand it, it should just require "wrapping" the `forward()` methods to do a reshape of the input, save the shape of the indexing/batch dimensions, then reshape the output to match that. We would still keep the convention of `(P, T)` and `(P, M, N)`, etc. for the last three, where `P` indexes the path.

I'm not sure I see much "hard-coding" of assumptions here. The meta information can map the path variable (i.e., the second-to-last in 1D, third-to-last in 2D, etc.) to lists of lists or anything else. The only restriction here is that all the coefficients be of the same `(M, N)` size. Now whether that is a good idea or not is up for debate.

> I should add that whatever decision we take should be informed by future plans of implementing routines for multivariables scattering transforms, including:
> 
>     * roto-translation
> 
>     * time-frequency
> 
>     * 1-D x 1-D  (images in which the horizontal and vertical dimensions are not physically homogeneous)
> 
>     * 1-D x 2-D (videos)

For the first two, I don't think this affects the the conventions. Roto-translation takes images (2D signals) as input, so would fall under `(M, N) -> (P, M/2**J, N/2**J)`. Similarly, time-frequency takes 1D signals and would fall under `(T,) -> (P, T/2**J)`. I think the other two would fall under similar conventions with a scattering path index that would index all the different coefficients.

Am I missing something here?

> Sure, but why should this make the scattering transform give "channels" special treatment? At the end of the day, it's just an indexing dimension that is not operated on.

To preserve the property that batch size remains fixed in every tensor of the computation graph
This property is very important in the age of batch normalization
Therefore I think that we need two dimensions that is not operated on: one to index homogeneous inputs (batch), one to index heterogeneous inputs (channels).
Having more than two is a nice to have but not a must have because we can always boil it down to two dimensions by reshaping.


> I'm not sure I see much "hard-coding" of assumptions here. The meta information can map the path variable (i.e., the second-to-last in 1D, third-to-last in 2D, etc.) to lists of lists or anything else. 

OK these are good news. I stand corrected.


> For the first two, I don't think this affects the the conventions.

Well in time-frequency scattering I could make the case that the output should be (at least optionally)
`(P, T/2**J, F)` where F is frequency so that we could run a 2-d convnet in the time-frequency domain further down the line. Granted the same could be said about time scattering to some extent, on the condition that `j2_min` > `j1_max`. Or is that rearrangement of dimensions something that should be considered post-processing, and completely separate from the bulk of computation?

> > Sure, but why should this make the scattering transform give "channels" special treatment? At the end of the day, it's just an indexing dimension that is not operated on.
> 
> To preserve the property that batch size remains fixed in every tensor of the computation graph
> This property is very important in the age of batch normalization
> Therefore I think that we need two dimensions that is not operated on: one to index homogeneous inputs (batch), one to index heterogeneous inputs (channels).

Of course. The batch size needs to remain the same when computing forward passes in a neural network. That being said, the `Scattering*D` object itself is not a neural network layer. It feels a little "above its pay grade" to think about channels, and so on. All we ask of it is to transform some data.

> Having more than two is a nice to have but not a must have because we can always boil it down to two dimensions by reshaping.

It's not just having more than two, but also less than two. I was discussing this with @eickenberg earlier (I forget where). It would be nice just to call a 1D scattering transform on a `(T,)` vector and get a `(P, T/2**J)` vector out. Or if we have a batch with only one channel, to call it on `(B, T)`, and so on. I really think such a dimension-agnostic (i.e. only acts on the last `d` dimensions) would make a for a more predictable interface.

> > I'm not sure I see much "hard-coding" of assumptions here. The meta information can map the path variable (i.e., the second-to-last in 1D, third-to-last in 2D, etc.) to lists of lists or anything else.
> 
> OK these are good news. I stand corrected.

While this information is in there, only 1D has a `meta()` function right now, and it's a bit of a mess. It would be good to think about how to define this in a consistent way for all scattering transforms in Kymatio (and beyond). I don't understand your lists of lists approach completely, but something like that could be good to have.

> > For the first two, I don't think this affects the the conventions.
> 
> Well in time-frequency scattering I could make the case that the output should be (at least optionally)
> `(P, T/2**J, F)` where F is frequency so that we could run a 2-d convnet in the time-frequency domain further down the line. Granted the same could be said about time scattering to some extent, on the condition that `j2_min` > `j1_max`. Or is that rearrangement of dimensions something that should be considered post-processing, and completely separate from the bulk of computation?

Sure, but, as you say, the `T-F` plane would have different sizes depending on `P`. It's not a "rectangular" tensor. What to do with the remaining space, fill with NaNs? I think this could get quite hairy. That being said, there should be easy ways to extract such slices, if desired, for the reasons you mention.

>  That being said, the Scattering*D object itself is not a neural network layer. It feels a little "above its pay grade" to think about channels, and so on. All we ask of it is to transform some data.

I disagree. from what I understand, a big advantage of Kymatio is that Scattering*D can be fed as input or output to a neural network layer. Isn't that part of the spec?
Also note that the batch size may change between training and prediction but the number of channels may not.
So the fundamental difference between batch and channel is that batch remains constant from layer to layer but may vary from pass to pass whereas it's vice versa for channels.


>  I was discussing this with @eickenberg earlier (I forget where). It would be nice just to call a 1D scattering transform on a (T,) vector and get a (P, T/2**J) vector out. Or if we have a batch with only one channel, to call it on (B, T), and so on. I really think such a dimension-agnostic (i.e. only acts on the last d dimensions) would make a for a more predictable interface.

But then how do you make the difference between (B, T) and (C, T) ? Isn't the conflation between batch and channel a potential source of bugs in pytorch autodifferentiation?


> While this information is in there, only 1D has a meta() function right now, and it's a bit of a mess. It wSure, but, as you say, the T-F plane would have different sizes depending on P. It's not a "rectangular" tensor. What to do with the remaining space, fill with NaNs? I think this could get quite hairy.

You are right but it becomes rectangular on the condition that j1_max < j2_min which is not unheard of in audio. No need for NaNs in this case. But we can always fill with zeros in the general case. It preserves energy. I'm OK with leaving this as post-processing but that represents a big operation of memory copy, which will slow down the code considerably. One of the core reasons why scattering.m is so fast is that the IFFT happens exactly where the coefficients need to be placed for the net layer.

> > That being said, the Scattering*D object itself is not a neural network layer. It feels a little "above its pay grade" to think about channels, and so on. All we ask of it is to transform some data.
>
> I disagree. from what I understand, a big advantage of Kymatio is that Scattering*D can be fed as input or output to a neural network layer. Isn't that part of the spec?

I'm not sure. For one, it doesn't inherit from `torch.nn.Module`, which seems to be the standard way to do this.

> Also note that the batch size may change between training and prediction but the number of channels may not.
> So the fundamental difference between batch and channel is that batch remains constant from layer to layer but may vary from pass to pass whereas it's vice versa for channels.

Sure, but to the scattering transform they're all the same (they're all batch-like dimensions). It doesn't do anything special with the channel dimension (except in the 1D case, where it errors if it's not size 1). Why give it special status? I understand that in a network, it may have special status, but why should the scattering transform care about this? `torch.fft` doesn't care.

> > It would be nice just to call a 1D scattering transform on a (T,) vector and get a (P, T/2**J) vector out. Or if we have a batch with only one channel, to call it on (B, T), and so on. I really think such a dimension-agnostic (i.e. only acts on the last d dimensions) would make a for a more predictable interface.
> 
> But then how do you make the difference between (B, T) and (C, T) ? Isn't the conflation between batch and channel a potential source of bugs in pytorch autodifferentiation?

Do you need to know the difference? Specifically, does the scattering transform need to? The computation, and the gradient, is the same. I don't see how it would break down the automatic differentiation. Could some PyTorch folks chime in here? @eickenberg @edouardoyallon?

> > Sure, but, as you say, the T-F plane would have different sizes depending on P. It's not a "rectangular" tensor. What to do with the remaining space, fill with NaNs? I think this could get quite hairy.
> 
> You are right but it becomes rectangular on the condition that j1_max < j2_min which is not unheard of in audio. No need for NaNs in this case. But we can always fill with zeros in the general case. It preserves energy. I'm OK with leaving this as post-processing but that represents a big operation of memory copy, which will slow down the code considerably. One of the core reasons why scattering.m is so fast is that the IFFT happens exactly where the coefficients need to be placed for the net layer.

It's not clear to me what `j1_max < j2_min` implies. At any rate, that's quite a strong constraint to impose to suit a scattering regime that is "not unheard of." Sure, you can fill with zeros and you may improve performance by copying less memory for some tasks, but for other tasks you're decreasing performance by unnecessarily multiplying by lots of zeros and increasing memory usage.

The 3D version returns different outputs for different versions.

- "standard" would return `(B,P, M/2**J,N/2**J,O/2**J)` 
- "integral" would return `(B,P,1,1,1)` (or `(B,P)` not sure)
- "local" would return `(B,P,1)`

The reason for "integral" is practically dimensionality reduction (among others) because  3D  is typically large. For "local" you have to ask @louity to be certain but I think it's to identify interesting regions in the moduli (e.g. midpoints between bonded atoms in quantum chemistry)

Cool. So can `integral` and `local` be computed from `standard`? The more we can standardize the function of the `forward()` functions, the better. It may be better to apply these transformations as post-processing, if possible.

Also, what's the purpose of the tuple structure? Is that necessary or could the Tensors be concatenated?
local probably not. Integral yes but it may be slower.

> Cool. So can `integral` and `local` be computed from `standard`? The more we can standardize the function of the `forward()` functions, the better. It may be better to apply these transformations as post-processing, if possible.
> 
> Also, what's the purpose of the tuple structure? Is that necessary or could the Tensors be concatenated?

Yes I can do that

> local probably not.

Hmm ok. Maybe best to leave this right now. Is it something that's used anywhere else?

> Integral yes but it may be slower.

Slower because it would leave large arrays unaveraged? As long as they stay in GPU memory, is it that bad? The caller can always average them later, right?

> > Also, what's the purpose of the tuple structure? Is that necessary or could the Tensors be concatenated?
> 
> Yes I can do that

Ok. Let's do that, then.

rename.to: scattering3d forward returns a tuple instead of tensor

rename.from: scattering3d forward returns a tuple instead of tensor
rename.to: scattering3d returns a tuple instead of tensor
